bibl.title: Letter from Mazyck P. Ravenel to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 23, 1925

div1.p: Ravenel refers to an article by Russell concerning the sanitation campaign in Havana (1900). In an autograph note, [Kean] writes that Ravenel has misunderstood Russell.

div1.head: Letter from Mazyck P. Ravenel to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 23, 1925
div1.opener:
BACTERIOLOGY AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI
COLUMBIA
September 23, 1925.
Colonel Jefferson R. Kean,
Medical Corps U. S. Army,
Library, Surgeon General's Office,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Colonel Kean:
div1.p:
I wonder if you have read the address by
Dr. F. F. Russell, published in the Sigma Xi quarterly for 1925.
Russell should know medical history and especially the history
of the Army, yet he gives full credit to Gorgas for cleaning up
Havana. Not a word does he say about General Black and Colonel
Havard, nor of his failure to prevent yellow fever by cleaning up.
He gives him full credit for having cleaned up Havana within 90
days, but does not say a word about preliminary work.

Very little credit is given to Carlos Finlay.
I would be the last one to desire to detract from the work of
Walter Reed, but Reed told me with his own lips that practically
the first thing he did was to consult Carlos Finlay and to receive
from him the eggs or larvae from which he bred his experimental
mosquitoes. Russell, however, says that the work of Henry F. Car-
ter probably induced Reed to change his original plan.

He makes another blunder in saying that Finlay
had announced the discovery of the cause of the disease. I believe
that we have everything that Finlay ever wrote and there is no such
claim that I know of. He does not mention the use of oil nor L. O.
Howard.

M. Tetracoco
25. Aug. 1895
Acnd de Sciencias
Habana
p. 289
Op. Gelac

I think I will write to Dr. Russell because
I dislike to see history so garbled. I am wondering if you are
Col. Jefferson R. Keen.
Page 2.
not in a position to call Russell's attention to these blunders?
They are worse if anything than those made by Mrs. Gorgas and Hen-
dricks, concerning which we have had some correspondence.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Mazyck P. Ravenal, M.D. MPR:LP
Dr Ravenel seems to have misunderstood
Dr Russell- They were talking about dif-
ferent things. The former had in mind the
physical cleaning of the streets and patios
while the latter referred to the mosquito campaign
of Gorgas
